questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presented with complaints of breathlessness and chest pain for 1 week. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. Her chest radiograph is given below. Which of the following findings is not consistent with rheumatoid arthritis being the cause of this condition?

choices.text: High glucose in the pleural fluid
High LDH in the pleural fluid
Presence of monocytes in the pleural fluid

questions.solution:
The given chest radiograph shows a left-sided pleural effusion. High glucose is not consistent with pleural effusion due to rheumatoid arthritis, since low glucose is expected in the pleural fluid analysis of this patient.

Pleural fluid analysis in a rheumatoid pleural effusion shows:

  • Gross appearance: turbid; green-yellow color
  • pH < 7.2
  • WBC count: up to 20,000 cells/μL, can be monocytes or neutrophils
  • Rheumatoid factor: positive
  • Glucose: low (< 60 mg/dL)
  • Cholesterol crystals present

Rheumatoid pleural effusion is a type of exudative pleural effusion. Light’s criteria are used to distinguish between exudative and transudative pleural effusions. An exudative pleural effusion satisfies at least one of the following criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds of the upper limit of normal serum value

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: A patient who underwent septoplasty, complains of pressure over the nose and difficulty in breathing on postoperative day 1. Local examination revealed smooth, round, soft, and fluctuant swellings on either side of the septum. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient with clinical features suggestive of septal hematoma is incision and drainage. 

Septal hematoma refers to a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It may be caused due to trauma, septal surgery (as in this patient), or spontaneously in bleeding disorders.

Patients usually present with bilateral nasal obstruction, pressure over the nasal bridge, or a frontal headache. On examination, smooth, round swellings, soft and fluctuant on palpation, can be seen on either side of the septum.

All septal hematomas must be drained to prevent the formation of septal abscess or fibrosis leading to a permanently thickened septum. A small anteroposterior incision is made parallel to the nasal floor. It must be followed by nasal packing. Smaller hematomas can be aspirated using a wide gauge needle. Patients should thereafter be started on systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: A woman underwent transvaginal cerclage under general anesthesia. Propofol was used for induction and succinylcholine was used for anesthesia maintenance. Even after 6 hours after the procedure, there were no signs of neuromuscular function recovery. Later, her dibucaine number was found to be 20. Identify the enzyme defect for the given condition.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of delayed recovery from a neuromuscular blockade by succinylcholine with dibucaine number 20, the defect is in the butyrylcholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase) enzyme. Dibucaine number 20 is seen in people with homozygous atypical butyrylcholinesterase which prolongs the action of succinylcholine to 4-8 hours. 

Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity. Dibucaine is a local anesthetic that inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits heterozygous atypical enzyme activity by 40-60% and homozygous atypical enzyme activity by only 20%. Accordingly, the patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80, and the patients with atypical pseudocholinesterase will have a lesser dibucaine number.

Succinylcholine and mivacurium are metabolized by the enzyme pseudocholinesterase. Some conditions like liver disease, pregnancy, advanced age, renal failure, major burns, and oral contraceptives might lead to the minimal prolongation of neuromuscular paralysis.

People with atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme will have reduced clearance of succinylcholine and mivacurium over time, thus prolonging the recovery time. Patients with one normal and one abnormal pseudocholinesterase gene (heterozygous) will have blockade for 20-30 minutes whereas patients with two abnormal genes (homozygous) can have blockade for up to 4-8 hours. It is treated with continued mechanical ventilation and sedation until the muscle function comes back to normal.

Other options:

Option A- Acetylcholinesterase metabolizes acetylcholine in the synaptic space.

Options B and C- Monoamine oxidase and catechol-O-methyltransferases are the enzymes that metabolize norepinephrine.

Related Pearl: Dibucaine number

  • High dibucaine number (80) means the high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: normal response to succinylcholine and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means the low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: prolonged succinylcholine and mivacurium block.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: A child presents with symptoms of fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis following his return from a summer camp. After a detailed workup, he was diagnosed with pharyngoconjunctival fever. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus which is a non-enveloped, space-vehicle-shaped dsDNA virus.

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute highly infectious illness with fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. The illness usually lasts for about 1-2 weeks followed by complete recovery. It is usually caused by serotypes 3, 7 and 14. It occurs usually, as outbreaks, in schools, summer camps, and prisons.

The following table shows various syndromes caused by adenoviruses and associated serotypes:

Syndrome Principle serotypes
Respiratory disease in children 1, 2, 5, 6
Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia 3, 4, 7, 14, 21
ARD in military recruits 4, 7, 21
Follicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis 3, 7
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye) 8, 19, 37
Diarrhea 40, 41

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Tissue culture, serodiagnosis, and polymerase chain reaction for detection of viral DNA may be used.

questions.text: Which layer of the cornea is affected in lattice corneal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Stroma is affected in lattice corneal dystrophy.

The corneal dystrophies are a group of progressive, usually bilateral, variable corneal opacifying disorders, many of which are associated with decreased vision and discomfort. Based on layers of the cornea involved, they are classified into epithelial, Bowman layer, stroma, and Descemet membrane and endothelial dystrophies.

Lattice corneal dystrophy

Lattice dystrophy affects the stromal layer of the cornea. The classic form of lattice corneal dystrophy has an autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused due to a defect in the TGFB1 gene. It is characterized by the presence of recurrent corneal erosions at the end of the first decade of age. The blurring of vision usually occurs later. 

On examination, a fine filamentous lattice that spares the periphery can be seen. It is associated with generalized stromal haze and reduced corneal sensation.

Histopathology will show the deposition of amyloid. These deposits stain with congo red stain and exhibit green birefringence on a polarised microscope.

It is treated by penetrating or deep lamellar keratoplasty.

 

 

Other corneal dystrophies that affect stroma are:

  • Granular corneal dystrophy

 

  • Schnyder corneal dystrophy

 

  • Congenital stromal corneal dystrophy

 

  • Fleck corneal dystrophy
  • Francois central cloudy dystrophy
  • Macular corneal dystrophy
  • Posterior amorphous corneal dystrophy
  • Pre-Descemet corneal dystrophy.

Other images of corneal dystrophies which affect layers other than stroma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man recently diagnosed with lung cancer presents with a worsening headache that is aggravated by stooping forward. On examination, he has facial and upper limb edema. His anterior abdominal wall appears as shown in the image with the arrow depicting the direction of subcutaneous venous flow. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing dilated tortuous superficial abdominal veins is suggestive of superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome seen due to superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction.

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is a clinical condition caused by the obstruction of the superior vena cava, which leads to impaired venous drainage from the head, neck, upper extremities, and upper torso. The most common cause is malignancy ( lung cancer, lymphomas, particularly non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and metastatic tumors). Non-malignant causes include thrombosis (caused by central venous catheters, pacemakers, or implantable defibrillators), fibrosing mediastinitis (e.g., due to tuberculosis or histoplasmosis), and aortic aneurysm or mediastinal fibrosis.

SVC syndrome is usually diagnosed clinically. Patients present with 

  • Facial puffiness and periorbital edema (worsens in the morning or when bending forward)
  • Jugular venous distension (JVD) and prominent veins on the chest wall
  • Dyspnea, cough, hoarseness, and stridor (if trachea is compressed)
  • Headache, dizziness, and confusion (due to cerebral venous congestion)
  • Edema and cyanosis of the upper limbs

The image below shows the direction of subcutaneous venous flow in various conditions.

A chest X-ray shows the superior mediastinum widening. A CT scan with contrast is the gold standard for identifying an obstruction's location, severity, and cause. Management is supportive and depends on treating the cause.

Other options:

Option A: Inferior vena cava obstruction occurs secondary to deep venous thrombosis, malignancy, pregnancy, and infection. Patients usually present with symptoms of decreased venous return such as fatigue, dizziness, weight loss, abdominal pain, night sweats, anorexia, palpitations, diaphoresis, dizziness, and shortness of breath on exertion. The direction of subcutaneous venous blood flow is from below to above. Inferior vena cava obstruction will not have facial or upper limb edema.

Option C: Cranial metastasis arises from the hematogenous spread and frequently originates from a lung primary or is associated with pulmonary metastases. Patients usually present with symptoms related to direct brain compression from the tumor or from edema. The location of the metastases will determine the focal deficits seen.

Option D: Tumor lysis syndrome is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It is commonly associated with treating lymphomas like Burkitt's lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Patients usually present with symptoms of hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: During your rotation in the forensic medicine and toxicology department, you notice the specimen of a fetus with a  length of 16 cm. What is the age of the fetus likely to be?
questions.solution:
The age of the fetus in months, calculated using the Rule of Haase, is √16 = 4 months. 

Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in months from its crown-heel length (in cm) in the first 5 months. It is a rough method of calculating the age of the fetus. During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months.

Haase's Modification of Morisson's Law:

During the last five months, the length of the fetus (in cm) divided by five gives the age in months.

Example - A fetus of length 40cm is likely to be 8 months old.

questions.text: What is the stain used in the given preparation for demonstrating H. pylori?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative rod and contains flagella. It is a risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. It causes gastric injury by releasing various virulence factors like γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), cytotoxin-associated gene A (cagA) product, virulence components vacuolating toxin (vacA), and lipopolysaccharides.

Important tests for the detection of H.Pylori are:

  • Rapid urease test
  • Histology
  • Culture
  • Serology
  • Urea breath test
  • Stool antigen test

Von Kossa stain demonstrating calcium and iron-containing Michaelis-Gutman bodies (MG bodies) in malakoplakia is shown in the image given below:

 

Alcian blue staining of mucin in Barret's mucosa is shown in the image given below:

questions.text:
A 42-year-old smoker presented at 28 weeks of gestation with worsening abdominal pain of a few hours duration. She had also had some vaginal bleeding within the past hour. She was found to have low-amplitude, high-frequency uterine contractions, and fetal heart rate measurement shows repetitive, late decelerations. Her uterus was tender and firm to palpation. What is the grade of placental abruption in this patient?

Vitals

Pulse - 112 bpm
BP - 110/70 mmHg
Temp - 36.8°C
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with vaginal bleeding, tachycardia, stable BP and fetal distress (Repetitive, late decelerations) is graded as grade 2 placental abruption.

Page clinical classification of placental abruption:

Features Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding Slight Mild-moderate Moderate-severe or concealed
Uterus Minimal tenderness Tenderness is present Marked tenderness
Maternal shock Pulse and BP maintained Pulse increased and BP maintained Shock is pronounced
Maternal coagulopathy Absent Absent May be present
Fetal condition Good Fetal distress Fetal death

Grade 0 presents with no clinical features and the diagnosis is made after delivery by inspecting the placenta. There is no grade 4 placental abruption.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with a history of chronic diarrhea, bloating, weight loss, and poor appetite for the past several months. A trial of antibiotic treatment a couple of months ago produced no significant clinical improvement. Her pulse rate was 82 beats per minute, BP was 110/78 mm of Hg, and the temperature was 98.6F. Laboratory investigations revealed anemia. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the histopathological findings are suggestive of celiac disease.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation and cause tissue damage. 

Microscopic findings on biopsy of the proximal small intestine will show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes.

Clinically, patients with celiac disease present with malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, chronic refractory anemia, and marked unintentional weight loss. Some patients may also present with dermatitis herpetiformis characterized by herpes-like vesicles that are caused due to the deposition of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Antiendomysial and anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are found in serological studies. Symptoms can be reversed by a gluten-free diet.

Other options:

Option A- Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is associated with tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy.

Option C- Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T.whipplei. Small intestine biopsy shows, PAS-positive macrophages.

Option D- Chronic pancreatitis affects the phase of intraluminal digestion is affected in which proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into forms suitable for absorption. These patients have fat malabsorption that presents as steatorrhea.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a swelling in her vagina. It is usually not painful but is troublesome during intercourse. On examination, a tender shiny swelling with well-defined margins is observed on the lateral vaginal wall. It is non-reducible and does not have any rugosities. Cough impulse is absent. The image of the swelling is given below. What causes this swelling?

choices.text: Prolapse of urinary bladder into vagina

questions.solution:
The given scenario is typical of Gartner's cyst. It arises from Gartner's duct, which is a remnant of the Wolffian duct in adults.

It is typically an asymptomatic cyst that is found on the lateral wall of the vagina. Symptoms, if present include dyspareunia, vaginal pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination findings include a tense swelling that is palpable or seen to bulge from beneath the vaginal wall.

Management involves excision or marsupialization of cyst in symptomatic cases

Other options

Option A - Epidermoid cysts (or epidermal inclusions) are skin-colored round-oval cysts commonly found on the vulva. It is caused due to traumatic implantation of epidermal cells into deep tissues or due to plugged pilosebaceous units.

Option B - Cystocele is the prolapse of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It appears as a reducible swelling with ill-defined margins, rugosities, and a cough impulse. It is often associated with urinary symptoms.

Option C - Bartholin glands produce mucus for the lubrication of the vulva and vagina. Obstruction of this gland leads to Bartholin cyst. It is identified by its anatomic location, i.e. lower medial labia majora or lower vestibular area. It is usually asymptomatic but becomes painful when infected.

questions.text: Which among the following pairs is an example of epimers?
questions.solution:
Glucose and mannose are examples of epimers.

Isomers differing as a result of variations in the configuration of the —OH and —H on carbon atoms 2, 3, or 4 of glucose are known as epimers. They differ only in one carbon atom. For example,

  • Mannose is an epimer of glucose at carbon 2
  • Galactose is an epimer of glucose at carbon 4

 

Compounds that have the same chemical formula but different structures are called isomers of each other. For example, fructose, glucose, mannose, and galactose all have the same chemical formula, C6H12O6, but they have different structures. The important types of isomers are:

  • D and L isomers/ Enantiomers- They differ in the orientation of the —H and —OH groups around the carbon atom adjacent to the terminal alcohol carbon (carbon atom 5 in glucose). If the -OH is present on the right side it is called D- isomer, if the -OH group is present on the left side it is called L isomer. Most of the naturally occurring sugars are D- sugars. They are mirror images of each other.

 

  • Anomerism- This is seen in the ring structure of carbohydrates. The orientation of -H and -OH differ in the 1st carbon atom. Eg. α-glucopyranose and β-glucopyranose.

 

  • Epimers- Isomers differing as a result of variations in the configuration of the —OH and —H on carbon atoms 2, 3, or 4 of glucose. Eg- mannose, and galactose are epimers of glucose at carbon 2 and carbon 4 respectively.
  • Aldose-ketose isomers- They have the same molecular formula but differ in the nature of the functional group. Eg. D-glycerose and dihydroxyacetone, D-xylose and D- xylulose, D-ribose, and D-ribulose, etc.
  • Optical isomers- They differ in optical activity. When a beam of polarised light is passed through a solution of the optical isomer, it can rotate the light either to the right side or to the left side. If the light deviates to the right it is dextrorotatory (+) and if the light deviates to the left it is called levorotatory (-). For eg. glucose in solution is dextrorotatory and naturally occurring fructose is levorotatory.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerve is most commonly damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows that the femoral head of the left hip is displaced upwards and laterally, and the affected limb is in adduction. Also, the lesser trochanter is obscured. These features indicate posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. The nerve the most commonly injured in this type of dislocation is the sciatic nerve.

Posterior hip dislocation occurs when the knee of the passenger strikes the dashboard. The affected leg is shortened, and lies in an adducted, internally rotated and slightly flexed position.

Imaging shows the following features:

  • Upward dislocation of the femoral head
  • The size of the femoral head appears smaller compared to the unaffected side
  • Adduction of the affected limb.
  • The lesser trochanter may not be visible due to the internal rotation of the affected leg

Treatment- A pure hip dislocation should be reduced as early as possible to reduce the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis. Important maneuvers to reduce posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Rochester method
  • East Baltimore lift
  • Allis
  • Bigelow
  • Stimson

Complications of posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Injury to the sciatic nerve
  • Injury to the superior gluteal artery
  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Secondary osteoarthritis
  • Myositis ossificans
  • Recurrent instability of the reduced dislocation

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male is posted for elective splenectomy in your unit. He is anxious regarding the surgery. You are asked to explain the procedures to him and obtain written informed consent. With regards to the possible complications that can happen post-splenectomy, which of the following statements is/are wrong?
  1. The most common complication that can be encountered post open-splenectomy is Overwhelming post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI) caused by capsulated organisms.
  2. Infections by pneumococci are most commonly encountered and generally occur within 1 month of surgery. 
  3. The Patient should be vaccinated with pneumococcal 7 valent vaccines at least 1 day before surgery. 
  4. There is a risk of thrombocytosis which can lead to thrombotic events. 
  5. Hemorrhage resulting from a slipped ligature is a possible immediate complication
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 3 are wrong

Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after open splenectomy while OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)is the most common fatal late complication of splenectomy.

Infections by capsulated organisms like pneumococci are very common but these usually occur in the first 2-3 years after surgery. 

Adult individuals are vaccinated with the Pneumococcal PPV 23 vaccine and not the 7 valent vaccine. These vaccines should be given 2 weeks before elective surgery.

Following splenectomy, the patients are more susceptible to infections with capsulated organisms. The commonly involved organisms are:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Escherichia coli

Currently, the standard of care for post-splenectomy patients includes immunization with the following within 2 weeks of splenectomy if the patient did not receive these before surgery:

  • Polyvalent pneumococcal vaccine (PPV23)
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b conjugate vaccine
  • Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine

Thrombocytosis occurs following splenectomy, particularly in patients with myeloproliferative disorders (e.g., chronic myeloid leukemia [CML], polycythemia vera, essential thrombocytosis). It can result in the thrombosis of the mesenteric, portal, and renal veins and can be life-threatening because it can lead to hemorrhage and thromboembolism. An immediate complication specific to splenectomy includes hemorrhage resulting from a slipped ligature.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

questions.text: A child presents with neonatal hypotonia, tachypnoea, abnormal eye movements, and mental retardation. On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a ‘batwing appearance’ as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the Molar tooth sign suggest the diagnosis of Joubert syndrome. The image shows an axial T2 weighted image at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles demonstrating the molar tooth sign.

Joubert syndrome:

These are a group of recessive congenital ataxia disorders in which typically there is

  • Neonatal hypotonia
  • Tachypnoea
  • Abnormal eye movements
  • Mental retardation associated with a particular pattern of cerebellar dysgenesis with a molar tooth-type malformation and vermis hypoplasia

MRI features :

  • The cardinal feature is the presence of a molar tooth sign which is created by a combination of
    • Midbrain hypoplasia with an
    • Abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa and
    • A failure of the superior cerebellar peduncles to decussate across the midline.
  • On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a batwing appearance
  • Cerebellar hypoplasia
  • Midline vermian cleft
  • Dysplastic small vermis
  • The midbrain is small

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following is a histone deacetylase inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of cutaneous T - cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Vorinostat is a histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of cutaneous T - cell lymphoma. 

It is indicated for use in patients with cutaneous T - cell lymphoma who have progressive, persistent, or recurrent disease on or following two systemic therapies.

HDAC are enzymes that catalyze deacetylation reactions of acetylated lysine amino acids in histones leading to the transcriptional activation of cellular genes.  

Overexpression of HDAC can be found in some cancers. Thus HDAC inhibitors can cause differentiation with the emergence of a more normal cellular phenotype or cause cell cycle arrest with an expression of endogenous regulators of cell cycle progression. Romidepsin is also an HDAC  inhibitor that can be used to treat cutaneous or peripheral T - cell lymphoma. 

Other options:

Option A: Panobinostat is an HDAC inhibitor that is indicated for the treatment of patients with multiple myeloma who have received at least 2 prior regimens, including bortezomib and an immunomodulatory agent.

Option B: Alemtuzumab is a CD52-directed cytolytic monoclonal antibody indicated for the treatment of patients with relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis and for treating B-cell CLL.

Option C: Denileukin difitox is a CD25-directed cytotoxin indicated for the treatment of patients with persistent or recurrent cutaneous T-cell lymphoma whose malignant cells express the CD25 component of the IL-2 receptor. It is a fusion protein of diphtheria toxin which inhibits protein synthesis. It is commercially unavailable at present.

questions.text: Which of the following would not favor a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension?

choices.text: Palpable second heart sound at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
Increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) will not favor a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Increased PCWP will be seen in post-capillary pulmonary hypertension (PH).

Pulmonary hypertension is broadly classified into:

  • Pre-capillary PH or PAH
    • Involves the pulmonary arterial system
  • Post-capillary PH
    • Involves the pulmonary venous system
    • PCWP ≥ 15 mmHg and
    • Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) < 3 Wood units.

Signs and symptoms of PAH

  • Dyspnoea and/or fatigue
  • Elevated JVP
  • Loud P2 (second heart sound), palpable in left second intercostal space
  • Right-sided S3 or S4
  • Murmurs in PAH
    • Tricuspid regurgitation - Holosystolic murmur
    • Pulmonary stenosis - Ejection systolic murmur
    • Pulmonary regurgitation - End diastolic murmur (Graham-Steel murmur) in severe PAH
  • Right heart failure in severe PAH - Peripheral edema, ascites, hepatomegaly.

Investigations in PAH

  • Chest X-ray
    • Enlargement of central pulmonary arteries
    • Rapid tapering of vessels known as vascular pruning
    • Right ventricular enlargement.
  • ECG
    • Features of RV strain such as right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Pulmonary function tests
    • Reduction in DLCO
    • Normal FEV1 and FVC if no underlying lung disease.
  • Definitive diagnosis of PAH is by cardiac catheterisation and will have all of the following:
    • Mean pulmonary arterial pressure, mPAP > 25mmHg (or >20 mmHg at rest)
    • PVR ≥ 3 Wood units
    • PCWP ≤ 15 mmHg. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Pulmonary Hypertension & its Causes

Based on underlying mechanisms, the World Health Organization has classified pulmonary hypertension into five groups.

Classification

Causes

  • Schistosomiasis

Group 2

Group 3

questions.text: An elderly man was brought to the hospital with complaints of rapid heartbeat, increased sweating, and dizziness. His ECG is shown below and his BP is 126/82 mm of Hg. The doctor asked him to lie down and turn his head to the left side. He then applied pressure on the right carotid artery just below the angle on the mandible, which lowered the patient's heart rate. Which among the following is the afferent nerve for the manoeuvre performed by the doctor?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). As the patient is stable, the doctor has performed a carotid sinus massage to slow the heart rate and to convert to sinus rhythm. This stimulates the baroreceptor reflex, whose afferent nerve is the glossopharyngeal nerve. 

Features suggestive of PSVT are:

  • Narrow complex tachycardia at 150 bpm
  • No visible P waves
  • Pseudo R’ waves in lead aVR due to retrograde atrial activation

Carotid sinus massage:

Procedure- It is performed with the patient supine and the head turned slightly away from the side being stimulated. Before performing massage the doctor should always auscultate to check for the presence of carotid bruit. If bruit is present, it should not be performed. The area of the carotid sinus, at the artery’s bifurcation, is palpated with two fingers at the angle of the jaw until a good pulse is felt. A minimal amount of pressure is applied over the carotid sinus. If there is no effect, a side-to-side or rotating motion of the fingers over the site is performed for up to 5 seconds. ECG should be performed to assess the response.

Mechanism- Pressure over the carotid sinus stimulates the baroreceptors. These signals are transmitted through small Hering’s nerves to the glossopharyngeal nerves and then to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. These signals inhibit the vasoconstrictor center of the medulla and excite the vagal parasympathetic centre. The stimulation of the vagus results in a slowing of impulse generation in the SA node and a slowing of conduction velocity in the AV node.  

Other vagal maneuvers which are used to treat cardiac arrhythmias and conduction abnormalities are,

  • Valsalva manoeuvre- the patient is placed in a supine or semirecumbent position and instructed to exhale forcefully against a closed glottis. The patient should maintain this strain for 10-15 seconds and then start breathing normally. It decreases the heart rate and can be used in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.
  • Diving reflex- A patient holds his breath and then immerses his face in the water at a temperature of 10-20 degrees Celsius. It results in bradycardia and can be used to terminate paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. 

Note- Vagus nerve is an afferent for the impulses from the aortic baroreceptors in the arch of the aorta.

questions.text: The physician explains the complications of diabetes and the need for compliance in simple terms to his illiterate patient. This is an example of which level of communication?
questions.solution:
This is an example of communication on an intellectual plane.

Communication on an intellectual plane involves giving empathetic, easy-to-understand explanations of their conditions and helping the patients develop insight into their ailments and their treatment plans. The doctor should take into account the fact that the patient's intellectual understanding may not be at the same level and, hence, put it in simple easy-to-understand terms.

For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communication on the following levels:

  • Communication on an emotional plane: Listening with empathy, building rapport, and ensuring openness and trust from the patient is part of this.
    • Example- Dr. X lending a sympathetic ear to the complaints made by the 84-year-old geriatric patient on his lingering backache is the emotional plane.
  • Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs and his/her cultural and lifestyle factors that may influence health and disease and to advise in terms that the patient would understand. 
    • Example- Dr. A, the hypertension clinic physician, making his dietary advice in terms that fit the already existing lifestyle pattern in that area is an example of understanding the cultural plane.

There is no such plane as the scientific plane in communication.
